Award.AwardTitle: Conference Title: Research Integration of Early Findings from Institution Transformation Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The adoption and sustained use of research-based instructional strategies are more likely to occur when institutions create environments and structures to support faculty efforts to switch to them. The Division of Undergraduate Education has created several grant opportunities to support institutional transformation in STEM instruction by providing institutional grants under the WIDER program during 2012 and 2013 and thereafter in the IUSE: EHR program in the Institutional and Community Transformation track. (WIDER stood for Widening the Implementation and Demonstration of Evidence-Based Reforms. IUSE: EHR stands for Improving Undergraduate STEM Education in the EHR Directorate.) This conference will assemble Principal Investigators and co-Principal Investigators on projects supported by those two programs, as well as allied NSF programs under the NSF-wide IUSE framework, e.g. IUSE: GEOPATHS, IUSE: RED, and IUSE: POLAR. To save transportation costs, it will piggyback on a national meeting of NSF grant recipients in an array of the aforementioned programs past and present. This meeting is scheduled for the spring, 2016. Following NSF's 4-year focus on transforming institutions through grants in order to overcome intra-institutional barriers to adopting research-based instructional strategies, there is now a substantial number of institutions engaged in spreading the use of evidence-based teaching approaches and associated efforts in assessment and evaluation. Each institution is engaged in a partly unique set of activities to increase and support the spread of research-based practices. The structure of the conference is designed to determine how different approaches are working in different institutional contexts in order to identify those that are robust to institutional setting and those that are more idiosyncratic to the host institution. In a single institution there is a tendency for the research team in each institution to be heavily influenced by the idiosyncrasies of their institution. By connecting across institutions, teams will be able to develop a broader perspective on the effectiveness of various strategies that can be deployed in service of the main goal of spreading effective teaching practices across the instructional faculty.

The primary purpose of this project is to conduct a research integration study of the preliminary findings of the projects supported by WIDER and IUSE: EHR. This integration study will provide a venue for research teams to compare results and share their understandings of what is working. The conference will lead to three outcomes: identification of successful strategies across a variety of institutional contexts, a synthesis of findings, and a network of sponsored projects for further follow-up. This conference will use the experience and expertise of the Principal Investigators through research integration by dialogue, using the approaches of a consensus conference and a consensus development panel through use of break-out sessions. A 7-step meta-ethnographic approach will be used.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 30 years, Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education research has documented many evidence-based teaching practices that can improve how students learn STEM topics. Unfortunately, getting teachers to adopt these practices has proven to be a challenging task unto itself. To address this challenge, the National Science Foundation (NSF) has funded efforts to increase adoption of evidence-based practices through programs such as the Widening Implementation & Demonstration of Evidence Based Reforms (WIDER) program. This project brought together leaders from 28 of these WIDER projects, at the end of their second year of funding, to share their early research findings and document what may be effective strategies for increasing adoption of evidence-based teaching practices. These WIDER projects were primarily composed of STEM education researchers, advocates, and college administrators.

Each of these teams collected a wide range of data including surveys, interviews, teaching observations, and social network data. Many teams reported feeling overwhelmed by the simultaneous tasks of trying to create change in STEM education at their instutions and conducting research on that change. This commonality suggests that future funding efforts should require careful planning to include not only STEM education researchers or administrators but also other researchers who focus on studying organizational change and culture. 

The project also identified a number of challenges and opportunities for creating sustainable change in STEM education teaching practices. As has been previously noted by many advocates, teams mentioned that many teachers are still generally unaware of evidence-based teaching practices and are not given the time or training to learn about these practices or how to implement them. Many teams also noted that students themselves are a major deterrent for implementing evidence-based practices as students frequently give poorer ratings to teachers who use more effective teaching methods. Many effective teaching methods place more responsibility on students to discover knowledge for themselves rather than simply be given that knowledge by a teacher. Consequently, students believe that the teacher is not doing their job, even if the teacher is helping the student learn faster and better.

More importantly, though, the teams discussed the importance of departmental culture and the structure of professional relationships. Participants noted that teachers paid less attention to the evidence that demonstrates whether a teaching method is effective and more to their colleagues' attitudes and perceptions of those teaching methods. If their colleagues are generally unaware or skeptical of evidence-based teaching practices, teachers are also likely to adopt this same attitude. Despite being scientists themselves, they trust their colleagues more than the science. Consequently, many of the WIDER teams had found that working to build communities of faculty who share a common vision for improving STEM education was more effective than simply mandating change or trying to persuade people to change with evidence. As these communities work together, they develop common values and beliefs that enable them to sustainably change their teaching practices.
